params.text:
Professional Writing

Write a Report 2:

Language in Action

• Refer to Other Parts of the Text/Graphics
  • Master Proofreading Strategies – Record, Revise, Reduce
  • Conclude with impact – Synthesize and Plan Actions
Professional Writing: Introduction

Now that you've mastered the essential first steps of crafting a report, let's delve deeper into refining and finalizing your work! 

Today, we'll focus on:

1. Referencing Other Parts of the Text/Graphics: Explore techniques for seamlessly referencing figures, tables, and charts within your report.

  2. Master Proofreading Strategies – Record, Revise, Reduce: We'll equip you with effective proofreading techniques using the "Record, Revise, Reduce" method. 

  3. Conclude with Impact – Synthesize and Plan Actions: Learn how to craft a compelling conclusion that summarizes your key findings.
Refer to Other Parts of the Text/Graphics: Key Points

When you include visuals like figures, tables, and charts in your report, it's crucial to reference them within the text to guide your reader and enhance understanding. 

Here are some strategies to remember:
Explicit Mention:

• Directly mention the specific figure or table you're referring to.
    Example Sentence: "As illustrated in Figure 3, our sales figures have steadily increased over the past quarter."
Use Numbering:

• Refer to the visuals using their corresponding numbers.
    Example Sentence: "Table 2 provides a detailed breakdown of customer demographics by region."
Descriptive Phrases:

• Use clear and concise phrases to identify the visual.
    Example Sentence: "The bar chart (see next page) highlights the significant growth in online versus in-store purchases."
Avoid Over-referencing:

• Don't simply repeat the information presented in the visual. Use your text to analyze, explain, or elaborate on the data.
    Incorrect Example Sentence: "The pie chart (Figure 1) shows that a majority of customers prefer online shopping. As you can see in Figure 1, online shopping is the most popular choice." (Redundant)
Placement:
• Generally, reference the visual within the sentence before it appears in the report, but after you've first introduced it.
Refer to Other Parts of the Text/Graphics: Exercise

params.textField:
A significant upward trend can be observed in website traffic over the past year, as *illustrated* in Figure 2. 
The pie chart on employee demographics (see *Appendix* A) *reveals* a well-balanced distribution across different age groups. 
To better understand the regional variations in customer preferences, we recommend *analyzing* Table 1 in more detail. 
Our key findings regarding brand awareness, as outlined in the *previous* section, clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of the marketing campaign. 
Although the bar *chart* (Figure 4) suggests a slight decrease in sales in the northern region, further investigation is needed to determine the exact cause.

metadata.title: Refer to Other Parts of the Text/Graphics sentences

params.text: Refer to Other Parts of the Text/Graphics - Listening & Quiz
Please listen to the opinions of three people and answer the questions below:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What does Jemima emphasize about referring to visuals?
answers:
Briefly describe the visual to help readers understand its purpose. 

It's best to avoid referring to visuals altogether. 

Use complex technical terms when describing the visuals

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Natasha suggest about using graphs and charts in reports?
answers:
Explain the meaning and importance of the data presented in the visuals.

Simply include the visuals without mentioning them in the text. 

Focus on using complex chart designs to impress the reader.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Ben's advice highlight about using data from tables?
answers:
Explain the meaning of the data and connect it to other aspects of your report. 

Include all the data from the table in your report, even if it's not relevant.

Present the data in tables without interpreting its significance in the text.

params.text: Jemima:

params.text: Ben:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Natasha:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Dialogue Text:

Jemima: In architectural reports, clear references to visuals are crucial! Don't just say "see the diagram." Describe it briefly - "The floor plan illustrates the optimal layout for maximizing natural light flow throughout the building." This helps readers understand the specific visual you're referencing.

Natasha: Graphs and charts are gold in marketing reports! But remember, they shouldn't speak for themselves. Always refer to them in the text and explain their significance. For example, "The social media engagement graph shows a spike following the launch of our new influencer campaign."

Ben: Numbers can be powerful, but context is key! Don't just quote data from a table without explaining its meaning. For example, "As shown in Table 1, a 15% increase in sales conversion rates was achieved in quarter 2. This can be attributed to our implementation of a new customer loyalty program.

params.textField: Proofreading is like *polishing* a diamond! Take your time and read through your report multiple times. Pay close *attention* to typos, grammatical errors, and sentence flow. Don't rely solely on *spellcheck* - it might miss things like subject-verb agreement or incorrect word choice.

(HR Manager):

params.textField: Proofreading is a *must* for professional reports! I find it helpful to read my work aloud. This can help you catch awkward *phrasing* or typos that you might miss when reading silently. Also, ask a *colleague* to proofread your report for a fresh *perspective*.

params.textField: For financial reports, accuracy is *paramount*! Double-check all figures and calculations. Even a minor mistake can have a big impact. Consider using the "reread-revise-reduce" method. First, reread your work for *errors*. Then, revise for clarity and conciseness. Finally, reduce *redundancy* and unnecessary phrases.

params.text:
Natasha
(Marketing manager):

Tarik
(Financial Manager):
What Would You Do? Quiz

choices.question:
Question 1 of 4: You've just finished writing a report on customer satisfaction. The report includes graphs showing customer ratings for different products.
What should you do as part of your proofreading process?
answers:
Double-check all the numbers and data points in the graphs to ensure accuracy. 

Quickly skim the report to check for overall flow. 

Ask a colleague to review the clarity and persuasiveness of your writing.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 4: You're writing a report on the company's environmental initiatives. After writing the first draft, you realize some sentences seem long-winded.
What proofreading technique from the passage would be most helpful?
answers:
Reread the draft for clarity and conciseness, identifying areas where you can reduce redundancy. 

Double-check the subject-verb agreement in every sentence. 

Ask a manager to review the report and ensure it aligns with the company's environmental goals.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 4: You've written a report on employee training programs. You're confident about the content, but you want to make sure there are no typos or grammatical errors.
What is the BEST way to start your proofreading process?
answers:
Reread the report carefully, focusing on identifying typos, subject-verb agreement, and grammatical mistakes. 

Read the report from beginning to end, highlighting any unclear sections. 

Put the report aside for a day or two and then come back to proofread with fresh eyes.

choices.question:
Question 4 of 4: You've written a report on a new marketing campaign. While proofreading, you find a sentence that sounds awkward when you read it aloud.
What should you do next?
answers:
Revise the sentence to improve the flow and phrasing. 

Ignore it - the meaning is clear enough. 

Ask a friend to read the sentence and see if they find it awkward as well.

params.text: Read the following scenarios and choose the best proofreading strategy to use in each situation.
Conclude with impact – Synthesize and Plan Actions
Please listen to the conversation between Tarik and Natasha and answer the questions below:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is the main point Natasha makes about the conclusion of a report?
answers:
It should summarize the key findings and highlight their significance. 

It should simply restate the facts presented in the report. 

It should be lengthy and include all the details from the report.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: In the conversation, how does Natasha suggest Tarik can make his conclusion more impactful?
answers:
Connect his findings to recommendations for future actions.

Include a funny anecdote to lighten the mood. 

Add complex financial jargon to impress the reader.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Natasha mention as an optional element Tarik could include in his conclusion, depending on the nature of his report?
answers:
A clear action plan based on the report's findings. 

​​​A detailed breakdown of the methodology used in the report.

An autobiography of his experience working on the report.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text: Tarik:
Natasha:
Dialogue Text:

Tarik: I'm finalizing my financial report, but I'm stuck on the conclusion. Any tips?

Natasha: Sure! The ending should be strong and memorable. Briefly summarize your key findings - the big takeaways from your report.

Tarik: Right, that makes sense. But how can I make it impactful?

Natasha: Don't just restate facts. Highlight the significance of your findings. For our marketing reports, we often connect them to recommendations for future campaigns. In your case, perhaps your report identifies areas for cost reduction or potential for revenue growth?

Tarik: Excellent point! I can definitely use my findings to suggest some budget optimization strategies.

Natasha: And if applicable, you can even outline a clear action plan. What are the next steps based on your report's conclusions?

Tarik: Great idea! I can recommend initiating a cost-saving program based on the data.

Natasha: See? A strong conclusion leaves your reader with a clear understanding of the key points and a sense of direction for moving forward

params.text: Please watch the following video and answer the questions:
What Would You Do? Quiz
Read the following scenarios and choose the best action to take when writing the conclusion of your report.

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: You've written a report analyzing customer feedback on a new product launch. The report highlights both positive aspects and areas for improvement.
What should your conclusion focus on?
answers:
Briefly summarize the key findings - what customers liked and disliked most about the product. 

Restate all the customer feedback verbatim, both positive and negative. 

End with a joke to lighten the mood after presenting the customer feedback.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 3: You've written a report on the effectiveness of a social media campaign. Your findings show a significant increase in brand awareness.
How can you strengthen the concluding section?
answers:
Briefly mention the increase in brand awareness and connect it to the potential for higher sales in the future.

​​​​​​Simply state that brand awareness has increased.

End with a detailed breakdown of the social media platforms used in the campaign.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 3: You've written a report on employee training needs within your company. The report identifies specific skills gaps.
What is an optional but valuable element you could include in the conclusion of your report?
answers:
A clear action plan outlining recommendations for addressing the identified skills gaps. 

A funny story about a training session gone wrong.

A detailed list of all the training courses currently offered by the company.

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Choose the BEST answer for each question to demonstrate your understanding of the key skills for concluding professional writing effectively.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: When referring to a figure or table in your report, it's generally best to:
answers:
Briefly describe the visual to help readers understand its purpose. 

Simply mention the visual's number without any explanation. 

Repeat all the information presented in the visual within your text.

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: When using a pie chart in your report, you should:
answers:
Briefly explain the data presented in the pie chart and its significance to your report. 

Let the chart speak for itself without any explanation in the text. 

Focus on using complex chart designs to impress the reader, even if it makes it harder to understand.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: The "reread-revise-reduce" method for proofreading involves:
answers:
Rereading for errors, revising for clarity, and eliminating redundancy. 

Focusing solely on using spellcheck to identify errors. 

Printing the report and highlighting any sections that seem unclear.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: When proofreading data in a report, it's crucial to:
answers:
Double-check all figures and calculations for accuracy. 

Skim the report quickly to check for overall flow. 

Read the report aloud to identify awkward phrasing.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: The main purpose of the conclusion in a report is to:
answers:
Briefly summarize the key findings and highlight their significance. 

Restate all the details and information presented throughout the report. 

Introduce new information not previously mentioned in the report.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: In your report's conclusion, you can optionally include:
answers:
A clear action plan outlining next steps based on your findings. 

A detailed breakdown of the methodology used in the report. 

A humorous anecdote to lighten the mood.
